JAY ELEVEN TO
MEET SWARTHMORE
Visiting College Has Veteran
Team
JAYS IMPROVE
Team Hopes To Make Late
Season Spurt
Next Saturday, November 9, the
Johns Hopkins University football
team meets Swarthmore College.
The game will be played on the
Homewood field. Dr. Van Orman
both hopes and expects the team to
go through for their second victory
of the season.
The Swarthmore team will be
practically the same one that defeated Hopkins last year 13 to 9.
Hopkins was ahead until the last
two minutes of play when a long
forward pass brought victory for
the Swarthmore team. This year
Swarthmore gave Pennsylvania a
mighty close run, which seems to
say that they will be a hard team to
put down. The Philadelphia team
was not so impressive last week
when it defeated the weak-Delaware
eleven 19 to 6. Therefore the improvement shown by the Blue Team
last Saturday points to a victory
tomorrow.

Price 5 Cents

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 8, 1929

Vol. XXXIV, No. 12

WORLD YOUTH IS
DISCUSSION SUBJECT
A discussion will be held
Sunday, at the International
Tea, in Levering Hall. Miss
Ruth Outland, of Holland,
will speak on the World Youth
Conference which was held at
Erde, Holland. On the basis
of this talk the group will discuss the World Youth Movement, especially in regard to
the United States and Germany. Miss Outland is from
the other side and her 'viewpoint should prove of interest.

ACTIVITY GOES ON IN BIOLOGY
LAB. IN MIDST OF MOVING
Perhaps the most interesting
place on the campus in regard to
curiosities is the Biology Laboratory (apologies to any freshman lectures or other freshman gatherings).
Here one may see specimens of
Cab pus Aquaticus quaintly labelled
"Homewood, 1926." There are also
several skeletons of gigantic Felis
Dontestica, otherwise known as common house cats, which were so unfortunate to stray on the University
campus.

them over hill and vale.
The laboratory is particularly
proud of its assortment of salamanders, although they do not rival
in size, the collection of last year.

DEBATING TRY-OUTS
TO BE HELD SOON
Dal Ghent, president of the
Debating Council, wishes to
announce that try-outs for the
University Intercollegiate Debating Teams, will be held
Tuesday, November 19, at
5.30 P. M., in Room B, second
floor, Levering Hall. Every
member of the student body,
whether or not he has had any
training in intercollegiate debating is invited to the tryouts. The two speakers who
seem most qualified at this
time will be given a trip to
New England during the
Christmas Holidays with all
expenses paid to represent the
University against northern
colleges. Other speakers will
be assigned places in short,
out-of-town debates, and home
debates with other universities.

NEWS

In a report of his which was read
at Levering Hall by J. W. Day, Dr.
Doran criticized the "halo placed
about drinking and wild parties by
older men and alumni" claiming this
encouraged the younger men to
drink and accept it as a part of university life.

Dean Berry disapproved of the
sensational statements made in this
conference, about drinking in college, as it creates a wrong impression about life in the University. He
said that he would have disapproved
if there had been a wet conference
which had cited such extreme cases.
Drinking, according to the dean, has
decreased in the last two or three
years not only here but at most colleges.

Several weeks past the residents
of the upper levels of the Alumni
Dormitory had slight difficulties
with their lighting system and petitioned the gods of the power house
to have compassion on them and
draw them forth from the darkness.
Accordingly this request was fulfilled and with seeming great goodwill. For numerous days electricians were busy entering rooms and
absconding with all the wiring that
could be taken from all types of
fixtures. However, they soon returned and replaced the purloined
wire with another variety in which
they were certain there were no defects and proceeded to connect the
lamps of the entire floor with new
shiny cord.

JAY ELEVEN TO
MEET SWARTHMORE
Visiting College Has Veteran
Team
JAYS IMPROVE
Team Hopes To Make Late
Season Spurt
Next Saturday, November 9, the
Johns Hopkins University football
team meets Swarthmore College.
The game will be played on the
Homewood field. Dr. Van Orman
both hopes and expects the team to
go through for their second victory
of the season.
The Swarthmore team will be
practically the same one that defeated Hopkins last year 13 to 9.
Hopkins was ahead until the last
two minutes of play when a long
forward pass brought victory for
the Swarthmore team. This year
Swarthmore gave Pennsylvania a
mighty close run, which seems to
say that they will be a hard team to
put down. The Philadelphia team
was not so impressive last week
when it defeated the weak-Delaware
eleven 19 to 6. Therefore the improvement shown by the Blue Team
last Saturday points to a victory
tomorrow.

Vol. XXXIV, No. 12

WORLD YOUTH IS
DISCUSSION SUBJECT
A discussion will be held
Sunday, at the International
Tea, in Levering Hall. Miss
Ruth Outland, of Holland,
will speak on the World Youth
Conference which was held at
Erde, Holland. On the basis
of this talk the group will discuss the World Youth Movement, especially in regard to
the United States and Germany. Miss Outland is from
the other side and her 'viewpoint should prove of interest.

Perhaps the most interesting
place on the campus in regard to
curiosities is the Biology Laboratory (apologies to any freshman lectures or other freshman gatherings).
Here one may see specimens of
Cab pus Aquaticus quaintly labelled
"Homewood, 1926." There are also
several skeletons of gigantic Felis
Dontestica, otherwise known as common house cats, which were so unfortunate to stray on the University
campus.

DEBATING TRY-OUTS
TO BE HELD SOON
Dal Ghent, president of the
Debating Council, wishes to
announce that try-outs for the
University Intercollegiate Debating Teams, will be held
Tuesday, November 19, at
5.30 P. M., in Room B, second
floor, Levering Hall. Every
member of the student body,
whether or not he has had any
training in intercollegiate debating is invited to the tryouts. The two speakers who
seem most qualified at this
time will be given a trip to
New England during the
Christmas Holidays with all
expenses paid to represent the
University against northern
colleges. Other speakers will
be assigned places in short,
out-of-town debates, and home
debates with other universities.

at Levering Hall by J. W. Day, Dr.
Doran criticized the "halo placed
about drinking and wild parties by
older men and alumni" claiming this
encouraged the younger men to
drink and accept it as a part of university life.

Dean Berry disapproved of the
sensational statements made in this
conference, about drinking in college, as it creates a wrong impression about life in the University. He
said that he would have disapproved
if there had been a wet conference
which had cited such extreme cases.
Drinking, according to the dean, has
decreased in the last two or three
years not only here but at most colleges.

Several weeks past the residents
of the upper levels of the Alumni
Dormitory had slight difficulties
with their lighting system and petitioned the gods of the power house
to have compassion on them and
draw them forth from the darkness.
Accordingly this request was fulfilled and with seeming great goodwill. For numerous days electricians were busy entering rooms and
absconding with all the wiring that
could be taken from all types of
fixtures. However, they soon returned and replaced the purloined
wire with another variety in which
they were certain there were no defects and proceeded to connect the
lamps of the entire floor with new
shiny cord.
